title: practice 1 initial text intro
body:
Scenario

 

Imagine you’re part of a high school tutoring program that works with your local elementary school. You and other students help younger kids with their writing projects.

 

Young writers improve when they get clear and specific feedback, but it takes a lot of time to read each writing assignment and give that level of support. To help each student grow as a writer, you decide to use AI to review their writing and provide personalized feedback.

title: practice 1 initial text intro
body:
Scenario

 

Imagine that you've just joined the Guest Experience team at Marriott Hotels. It's your job to respond to customer messages—whether that's helping with a reservation, fixing a billing issue, answering a question about hotel services, or responding to a complaint.

 

You choose to use AI to help you reply to customer messages more efficiently and with a consistent tone. To guide the AI in generating responses that match Marriott Hotels’ brand voice, you create a few-shot prompt. This prompt includes examples of the kind of replies you want the AI to model.

title: Step 1: Write a Few-Shot Prompt text block
body:
Step 1: Write a Few-Shot Prompt

 

Use the Marriott Hotels brand guidelines below to create a few-shot prompt. Your goal is to help an AI respond to a variety of customer messages in a way that reflects the company’s voice and values.

 

Mariott Hotels Brand Guidelines:

 

Remember, a good few-shot prompt includes a clear task and two or three examples to show what kind of response you want. In this case, the task is replying to customer messages, so your examples should be made-up replies to a couple of customer messages.

title: Step 1 text input

_hint.title: Need Help Getting Started? Here's a Hint!
_hint.body: Use this format for your prompt:  Based on the following examples, [add your task/scenario instructions here].  Example 1: “[Add your example output here]”  Example 2: “[Add your example output here]”  If you like, try this for one of your examples:  Example 1: Customer message: "Could I upgrade my room?" Response: “Thank you for reaching out, Marc. We’d be happy to assist with a room upgrade for your upcoming stay. Availability can vary, so we recommend contacting our reservations team directly or visiting the front desk upon arrival for the most up-to-date options. If you’d prefer, we can also note your request in your reservation and follow up shortly. Please let us know how you’d like to proceed—we’re here to make your visit as comfortable as possible.”

instruction: Paste your few-shot prompt and press Submit

_items.title: Need Help Getting Started? Here's a Hint!
_items.body:
Use this format for your prompt:

 

Based on the following examples, [add your task/scenario instructions here]. 

Example 1: “[Add your example output here]”

Example 2: “[Add your example output here]”

 

If you like, try this for one of your examples:

 

Example 1:
Customer message: "Could I upgrade my room?"
Response: “Thank you for reaching out, Marc. We’d be happy to assist with a room upgrade for your upcoming stay. Availability can vary, so we recommend contacting our reservations team directly or visiting the front desk upon arrival for the most up-to-date options. If you’d prefer, we can also note your request in your reservation and follow up shortly. Please let us know how you’d like to proceed—we’re here to make your visit as comfortable as possible.”

title: test your prompt text block
body:
Now, test your few-shot prompt on the following customer messages:

 

  • “Does the hotel have an airport shuttle?”
  • “I was charged twice for my stay—can someone help? Thanks, Bruce”
  • “I left my headphones in the room—can I get them back?”
  • “Can I check in early? - Sara”
  • “My room was really noisy—I barely slept.”

title: Reflect text
body:
How did your few-shot prompt do?

 

  • Did the AI match Marriott’s tone?
  • What made it feel on-brand or off-brand?
  • Are the outputs clear and helpful?
  • What would you change to improve the examples?

title: Extension
body: Want to keep going? Try changing your prompt by using two new examples and see how the outputs change.

title: New Component Title
body:
Great Work!

 

You’ve just learned a powerful new skill: few-shot prompting. Use it whenever you have a clear idea of the output you want or examples to guide the AI.

title: Step 1: Write a Few-Shot Prompt text block
body:
Step 1: Write a Few-Shot Prompt

 

Use the feedback guidelines below to create a few-shot prompt. Your goal is to provide feedback that is kind, clear, and easy to follow—something that builds confidence and supports learning.

 

Feedback Guidelines

 

Remember, a good few-shot prompt includes a clear task and two or three examples to show the kind of response you’re aiming for. In this case, the task is giving feedback on elementary students’ writing, so your examples should be made-up feedback to sample writing assignments.

title: Step 1 text input

_hint.title: Need Help Getting Started? Here's a Hint!
_hint.body: Use this format for your prompt:  Based on the following examples, [add your task/scenario instructions here].  Example 1: “[Add your example output here]”  Example 2: “[Add your example output here]”  If you like, try this for one of your examples:  Example 1: Customer message: "Could I upgrade my room?" Response: “Thank you for reaching out, Marc. We’d be happy to assist with a room upgrade for your upcoming stay. Availability can vary, so we recommend contacting our reservations team directly or visiting the front desk upon arrival for the most up-to-date options. If you’d prefer, we can also note your request in your reservation and follow up shortly. Please let us know how you’d like to proceed—we’re here to make your visit as comfortable as possible.”

instruction: Paste your few-shot prompt and press Submit

_items.title: Need Help Getting Started? Here's a Hint!
_items.body:
Use this format for your prompt:

 

Based on the following examples, [add your task/scenario instructions here]. 

Example 1: “[Add your example output here]”

Example 2: “[Add your example output here]”

 

If you like, try this for one of your examples:

 

Example 1:
“Hi Maya! Great job describing the dragon in your story — I could really picture its shiny scales and big wings! You also did a nice job organizing your ideas from beginning to end. Next time, you might try adding more about how your character felt during the adventure. That would help your readers feel even more connected to the story. Keep up the great writing!”

title: test your prompt text block
body:
Now, test your few-shot prompt on the following  writing samples:

 

  • “My Favorite Animal – by Aiden | My favorite animal is a dog. I like dogs. They are fun. I like to play with dogs. Dogs are nice. My dog is brown. He like to run. I run with my dog. He is fun. I like my dog. He is nice.”
  • “My Weekend – by Zoe | On Saturday I went to the park. I played with my brother. We went on the swings. Then we got ice cream. It was fun. On Sunday we stayed home. I played video games. I also helped my mom with cooking. Then I watched a movie. I had a good weekend.”
  • “By Marcus | One time I felt proud was when I learned how to ride my bike. At first, I was scared because I kept falling. My dad helped me by holding the seat while I tried. After a few tries, I was able to ride all by myself! I felt happy and proud because I didn’t give up. Now I ride my bike all the time. It reminds me that I can do hard things if I keep practicing.”
  • “If I Had a Superpower – by Priya | If I had a superpower, I would choose to fly. I could fly over cities and mountains and see everything from the sky. I would use my power to help people who are lost or stuck in traffic. I’d also fly to school so I wouldn’t be late! Flying would feel like being free, like a bird in the wind. I’d wear a bright blue cape and goggles to keep the bugs out of my eyes. It would be the best superpower ever.”
  • “By Leo | My best friend is Tyler. We met in second grade. He is funny and nice. We like to play soccer and ride bikes. He is good at drawing. One time we made a comic book together. It had superheroes and robots. We also like to eat pizza. Sometimes we have sleepovers and stay up late. I like being his friend because he listens to me and makes me laugh. We sometimes fight but we always say sorry. He is my best friend because we have fun and help each other.”

title: Reflect text
body:
How did your few-shot prompt do?

 

  • Did the AI sound like a supportive tutor or mentor?
  • Would an elementary student feel proud or confused?
  • What changes might improve the tone, word choice, or next steps?
  • How did your examples help shape the AI’s voice?

title: Extension
body: Want to keep going? Try adjusting your prompt examples so that the tone is more effective for high school or university students and see how the outputs change.

title: What is Few Shot Prompting Text Block
body: Want your AI outputs to sound more like you? Few-shot prompting is a simple way to guide the AI by showing it a few examples of what you're looking for—not just telling it. In this quick video, you’ll see how just two or three examples can help the AI match your tone, style, or format—whether you're writing captions, emails, or anything else. Check it out!

title: What’s missing from this prompt if you want to use few-shot prompting?
body:
What’s missing from this prompt if you want to use few-shot prompting?

 

“Write a summary of this article in a casual tone.”

title: Which of these is an example of a few-shot prompt?
body: Which of these is an example of a few-shot prompt?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompts include a few examples before asking for a new response.

_items.text: "Here are two sample headlines I like: – Small Steps, Big Change – Science in Motion Now write a headline for a story about clean energy."
_items.feedback: Correct! Few-shot prompts include a few examples before asking for a new response.

_items.text: List three reasons why recycling is important.
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompts include a few examples before asking for a new response.

_items.text: "How many planets are in the solar system?"
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompts include a few examples before asking for a new response.

_feedback.correct: That's right! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

title: When would you want to use a few-shot prompt?
body: When would you want to use a few-shot prompt?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: When you want the AI to come up with something completely random
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompts are useful when you have a clear idea of what the output should look like—such as matching your tone or writing style.

_items.text: When you want the AI’s response to match a specific tone, format, or style
_items.feedback: That's right! Few-shot prompts are useful when you have a clear idea of what the output should look like—such as matching your tone or writing style.

_items.text: When you want the AI to follow a strict set of instructions, step by step
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompts are useful when you have a clear idea of what the output should look like—such as matching your tone or writing style.

_items.text: When you want the AI to explain how it arrived at its answer
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompts are useful when you have a clear idea of what the output should look like—such as matching your tone or writing style.

_feedback.correct: That's right! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

title: What is few-shot prompting?
body: What is few-shot prompting?
instruction: Choose {{#if _isRadio}}one option{{else}}one or more options{{/if}} then select Submit.

_items.text: A technique where you ask the AI to explain its reasoning step-by-step before giving an answer
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

_items.text: A technique where you include a few examples in your prompt to guide the AI’s response
_items.feedback: That's right! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

_items.text: A technique where you give the AI a single instruction with no examples
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

_items.text: A technique where you give the AI a detailed list of steps to follow in a specific order
_items.feedback: Not quite! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

_feedback.correct: That's right! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

_incorrect.final: Not quite! Few-shot prompting involves showing the AI a few examples of what you want, so it can follow that pattern when generating a new response.

title: Optional text block
body:
Optional: Keep experimenting

 

  • Include examples with different tones (funny, serious, luxurious)
  • Ask for a slogan and a tagline
  • Generate slogans for a completely different kind of business

title: Step 3: Reflect and compare the two outputs
body:
Step 3: Reflect and compare the two outputs

 

  • Which slogan would you actually use—and why?
  • How did adding examples shape the AI’s response?
  • Try changing your examples and running it again. What shifts?
instruction: Type your answer and press Submit

body:
Step 3: Add a few slogans you lik

 

Find or invent 2–3 slogans you like. Then revise and resubmit your prompt.

title: part 2 step 1 text block
body:
Part 2: Try it on your own

Now practice writing a few-shot prompt from scratch

 

Step 1: Choose a business idea

 

Create your own or pick one of these:

  • A tutoring service for middle schoolers
  • A mobile app that helps people find local hiking trails
  • A snack delivery service
  • An eco-friendly cleaning product line

 

Step 1: Choose a business idea

 

Write a basic prompt, then submit it and review the output.  

 

[add a trickle wait here for prompt playground to confirm text is submitted]

title: Step 3: Reflect and compare the two outputs
body:
Step 3: Reflect and compare the two outputs

 

  • Which version worked better?
  • What changed when you added examples?
  • Did the AI match the tone of your favorite slogans?
instruction: Type your answer and press Submit

title: part 2 step text block
body:
Step 2: Turn it into a few-shot prompt

 

Add a few slogans you like from other brands.

 

Here are three slogans I like:
– “Just Do It” (Nike)
– “Think Different” (Apple)
– “Because You’re Worth It” (L’Oréal)
Now, write a short slogan for a company that helps students explore future careers.

 

Submit the new prompt and review the output!

 

[add a trickle wait here for prompt playground to confirm text is submitted]

title: Part 1: Step 1 text block
body:
Step 1: Try a zero-shot prompt

 

Start with this simple prompt:

 

Write a short slogan for a company that helps students explore future careers.

 

Submit it to the AI tool and look at the output.

 

[add a trickle wait here for prompt playground to confirm text is submitted]

_items.title: Caption Example
_items.body: Here, the prompt asks the AI to write a caption for a picture of a science fair. It includes two example captions to guide the AI’s tone and style.

_items.title: Technical Jargon Example
_items.body: In this prompt, the AI's task is rewriting highly technical language so it’s easier for students to understand. The prompt includes two examples to show what a strong rewrite looks like, giving the AI a reference point.

_items.title: Blog Post Example
_items.body: In many AI models, you can attach files to your prompts. Here, the prompt asks the AI to write a blog post and includes three example blog posts (as PDFs) to guide the output.

_items.title: Classification Example
_items.body: Here, the prompt asks the AI to classify various sentences by the emotion they express. It includes three examples that show the format the AI should follow in its output.

title: Hot Graphic block
body: Now that you understand the key ideas, you’re ready to try it out. Here’s a general template you can use when writing few-shot prompts.
mobileInstruction: Select the plus icon followed by the next arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Task or Scenario
_items.body: Start with a clear, concise task or scenario for the AI to complete.

_items.title: Examples
_items.body:
Include two or three examples for the to use when generating its output.

 

(Be sure to tell the AI to refer to the examples when generating its output!)

title: Review it text
body:
Let’s quickly recap the most important things to remember about few-shot prompting.

 

  • What it is: Few-shot prompting means including a few examples of the output you want directly in your prompt—you're showing the AI what good looks like.
  • How it works: Examples help the AI learn your preferred tone, structure, and style, so its responses better match your expectations.
  • When to use it: Use few-shot prompting when you want a specific kind of output—like matching a particular voice, format, or creative style.
  • How to do it: Just add two or three clear examples before your request. You can use this strategy for captions, emails, summaries, stories—anything where quality and tone matter.
  • Tips for writing few-shot prompts: Choose clear examples that match the task, keep the steps short and specific, and include examples that cover a range of situations so the model can apply what it learns more broadly.
